criteria: Understanding Patterns in Zeros When Multiplying by Powers of 10
Understanding Decimal Placement When Multiplying or Dividing by Powers of 10
Using Whole-Number Exponents to Denote Powers of 10
descriptions: Cannot explain any patterns in the number of zeros when multiplying by powers of 10.
Can identify some patterns but struggles to explain them clearly or accurately.
Can explain simple patterns in the number of zeros when multiplying by powers of 10, but not complex ones.
Can clearly explain most patterns in the number of zeros when multiplying by powers of 10.
Demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of patterns in the number of zeros when multiplying by powers of 10, including complex cases, with clear and accurate explanations.
Cannot explain the placement of the decimal point when multiplying or dividing by a power of 10.
Can identify some shifts in decimal placement but struggles to explain the underlying reasons.
Can explain decimal placement for simple cases, but not for more complex powers of 10.
Can accurately explain decimal placement for most powers of 10, with minor errors.
Demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of decimal placement when multiplying or dividing by any power of 10 with clear and accurate explanations.
Does not use or incorrectly uses whole-number exponents to denote powers of 10.
Can sometimes use whole-number exponents, but with frequent errors.
Uses whole-number exponents correctly for simple powers of 10 (e.g., 10^2, 10^3), but struggles with larger exponents.
Uses whole-number exponents correctly to denote most powers of 10.
Consistently and accurately uses whole-number exponents to denote powers of 10, including very large exponents, and can explain the relationship between the exponent and the number of zeros.
